category.Title: Product Opportunity
category.Paragraph: With the creation of a new internal design system and framework, I worked on redesigning our existing product to meet our new design specifications and iterate upon the existing platform.

category.Title: Design Overview
category.Paragraph: I worked with two other UX designers on this 3 month project. I focused on leading design critiques and review sessions with internal stakeholders, working across teams to determine the scope of the MVP release and owning some of the specific designs of the overall redesign.
category.caption: The user interface before getting redesigned

category.Title: Key Use Cases
category.Paragraph: The initial scope of the application redesign was enormous. Research was conducted to distill the key use cases we wanted to resolve in the first launch.

category.Subtitle: Our modelling of projections did not match users' mental model.
category.Paragraph: Our initial display used a tabbing format to allow users to compare different scenarios. However, we saw user confusion. They did not understand why the values are changing and why not all of the values changed.

category.Subtitle: The application load time was not proportional to payoff for users.
category.Paragraph: In areas where our application takes a long time to load, users were dropping off. It was clear we needed to decrease the load time as well as improve our loading pattterns.

category.Subtitle: The primary dashboard was too cluttered
category.Paragraph: Because the existing visual hierarchy of the dashboard had many items on the same level, there was no clear indicator as to what users should be paying the most attention to. There was no differentiation between items that were prone to change and items that are seldom accessed.

category.Title: Redefined Problem Statement
category.Paragraph: How can we simplify the cognitive load of our application for users?

category.Title: Research Highlights
category.Paragraph: Research was conducted in the form of a card sort exercise, online surverys, and usability hotspot testing to inform the intial use cases listed above as well as to iterate into our final solution. Particularly, research informed the information architecture and subsequent site map of the new dashboard.
category.caption: A diagram of the new layout, which simplified the experience and made a clearer separation between items that were typically static  as opposed to changing content

category.Title: Design Highlights
category.Paragraph: While there were many things we wanted to change in the new application, our key use cases allowed us to hone in on what we would be solving for in this launch. Not only did we make changes for this application, we also developed design system guidelines from these solutions.

category.Subtitle: Improved content through consistency
category.Paragraph: A content review was undertaken,  reviewing the copy, such as help text and info buttons, leading to standardized key terminology to reduce the vocabulary on the page.  Additionally, rules for displays of numbers were put in place, allowing for consistent expecatations of rounding and precision.

category.Subtitle: Engaged loading times
category.Paragraph: Taking notes from gaming loading screens, the existing loading screens were replaced with loading screens that gave users something to look at while they waited. Additionally, instead of constant loading, information was loaded on an as-needed basis.

category.Subtitle: Side-by-side comparisons
category.Paragraph: In the previous tabbing style, the two scenarios could not be seen side-by-side; users would need to memorize the differences themselves. By placing the two scenarios on the same page, users were better able to draw their own conclusions to pros and cons.
category.caption: The redesigned dashboard

category.Title: Conclusion
category.Paragraph: Not only does this new redesign make use of our new visual design library, it also puts into place user experience guidelines from content strategy to interaction design patterns. The simplified experience also provided a stronger case for our product's value add, leading to increased sales.
